awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant Proposal for 2022 New England Hardware Security Day (NEHWS2022)
awd_abstract_narration:
NEHWS 2022 is an event jointly organized by faculty at Northeastern, UMass Amherst, Yale and Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI). NEHWS 2022 will be held as a one-day workshop on April 1, 2022 in the Marriott Center at UMass Amherst. This travel grant supports  students to attend NEHWS. Having explicit funding to support students allows the organizers to include more students among the attendees.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
New England Hardware Security Day (NEHWS 2022) was a 1-day workshop held on April 1, 2022 at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. The workshop had a total attendance of 88, of which 61 were students. This NSF travel grant supported student attendance at the workshop. The workshop featured 24 student-presented posters in the poster competition, and a lineup of outstanding talks, tutorials, and a panel.

Srinivas Devadas gave the keynote talk on "Hardware Acceleration of Cryptographic Primitives and Protocols." Mengjia Yan gave an invited talk on "Security Analysis of Misunderstood Micro-architectural Side-Channel Attacks and Mitigations", and Jens-Peter Kaps gave a second invited talk on  "Benchmarking FPGA Implementations of Candidates in the NIST Lightweight Cryptography Standardization Process". Colin O'Flynn gave the tutorial "Hands on with Non-Invasive Hardware Security Tooling."

The panel discussed "Driving Forces of Innovation in Security of Microelectronics Supply Chain" and featured the distinguished panelists Peter Grossmann from Intrinsix Corp, Elke De Mulder from Rambus, Richard Newell from Microchip Technology, John Oakley from SRC, and Ingrid Verbauwhede from KU Leuven.

The event was jointly organized by researchers from Northeastern University, UMass Amherst, Worcester Polytechnic Institute, and Yale. The organizing committee was Yarkin Doroz, Yunsi Fei, Fatemeh Ganji, Daniel Holcomb, Patrick Schaumont, Berk Sunar, Jakub Szefer, Shahin Tajik, and M. Caner Tol. The event helped to strengthen bonds within the New England hardware security community, and exposed students to state-of-the-art research topics in a field of major importance to our region.


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Daniel Holcomb
